Margaret Sanger Microfilm, Smith College Collections S70:1060

headNote.p: Sanger likely used these speech notes when she made the opening address at the Second Annual Meeting of the American Birth Control League, held in New York. Other speakers included Frances B. Ackermann, Anne Kennedy, and Annie Goodrich Porritt

docBody.p: I wonder how many of you here tonight realize just how much significant this gathering is means. How many of you realize that this meetingof intelligent representative citize4ns brought together by an interest in birth means control represent the year of struggle and effort. Ten years!
Ten years of battling against ignorance and prejudice. A ten year fight for the right to get people to talk and to think about the greatest problems that confront the human race.

For there are few subjects which leave so large a practical segregation and at the same time cut so deeply into the foundation of social evolution as birth control There are few other questions of Equal obscurity and yet none perhaps which can show so unequalled a leap in our Social Vista as birth control has done in so brief a period of time

The fundamental reason for such interest are two. That civilization is confronted with two serious problems. 1 That of the pressure of population upon the food supply. 2 That of reconsidering Humanitarian with race improvement.
Many of us realize that birth control is the key to their birth.
Mark Twain said: "everybody talks about the weather but no one ever seems to do anything about it"-
Well- The american B.C League is doing something about these problems.
We believe that words, theories, sentiment, sympathy are all very well in but we have got to have intelligent thinking put into intelligent action.

If the programs for birth control is to grow, to expand, if it is even to hold the ground it has gained through untold sacrifice and seemingly hopeless effort, we must have cooperation courageous cooperation of individual and organizations who accept the truth of birth control but do nothing about it. We need more English Courage in America.
We need the build of intellectual courage such as Dean Inge, Bernard Shaw, John Maynard Keynes, Lord Dawson the Kings physician, leave a private conviction publically expressed.
These men have the courage to express their private convictions, publically.
Nor have they lost in the estimation of the British public by doing so-
The ABCL is calling for the cooperation of the medical professionals for scientific research, for investigative and unbiased study.
